Comment:
Hi, this is Ren and I would like to show you my first game here of GameKnot.
My opponent was 412364, who had black pieces; I, with white, started with d4.
My opponent plays d5, giving a Closed Game opening.
c4: Queen's Gambit...
...and now Nf6, defending the pawn on d5.
The idea behind e3 was to defend the c4 pawn with the light-square bishop, although taking on d5 may have been a better continuation.
Again, it would have been better for me to have played cxd5, as after the knight recaptures, this move, Nf3, could allow for 5.e4.
Again, it would have been better for me to have played cxd5, as after the knight recaptures, this move, Nf3, could allow for 5.e4.
Here, my opponent's bishop is developed nicely, sitting behind the d5 pawn.
Perhaps not the best move in the circumstances, blocking off a diagonal for a potential bishop on d2.
7.Bd3 is a bit of a mistake, conceding the tempo with a knight fork on bishop and queen.
7.Bd3 is a bit of a mistake, conceding the tempo with a knight fork on bishop and queen.
7.Bd3 is a bit of a mistake, conceding the tempo with a knight fork on bishop and queen.
7.Bd3 is a bit of a mistake, conceding the tempo with a knight fork on bishop and queen.
7.Bd3 is a bit of a mistake, conceding the tempo with a knight fork on bishop and queen.
Black opts not to capture the bishop on d3, which may have been the strongest move, instead advancing the knight to g4.
Black opts not to capture the bishop on d3, which may have been the strongest move, instead advancing the knight to g4.
a3, with the aim to kick the knight back, seeing as black is reluctant to exchange it for my bishop.
? A mistake by my opponent, leaving me to capture free material.
After the dust has settled, I am a piece up.
After the dust has settled, I am a piece up.
After the dust has settled, I am a piece up.
Check is given for the first time...
...I decide to block with my knight.

Looking at the game now, is seems rather obvious in retrospect that I was given the opportunity to push my pawn to c5, forcing the bishop back to c7. Incredibly enough, neither of us saw it, and despite me having numerous opportunites to advance the pawn, it would forever remain on the fourth rank.

Live and learn, I suppose...
...Instead, I kick the knight on g4 back with h3.
...Instead, I kick the knight on g4 back with h3.

Probably played a move too early, looking back.
At this point I was expecting to see my opponent capture my pawn on c4, breaking my pawn structure on the queenside. However, as it happenned...

? Again I am puzzled by this sacrifice.
I hesitated quite a while, thinking this could be a trap, however I resolved that it was free material a second time after not seeing any winning variatons for black.
I'm a tad peturbed by this move, I'm thinking black's queen is coming to e8 to exploit the open e-file.
